courses.title: Introduction to Physics
courses.description: Fundamental concepts of motion, forces, and energy.

subtopics.title: Speed
subtopics.content:
# Speed

Speed is the distance travelled per unit time.

It is a scalar quantity, meaning it has magnitude but no direction.

## Formula

```
Speed = Distance / Time
```

## Units

- meters per second (m/s)
- kilometers per hour (km/h)
- miles per hour (mph)

## Example

If a car travels 100 km in 2 hours, its speed is:

```
Speed = 100 km / 2 h = 50 km/h
```

subtopics.title: Velocity
subtopics.content:
# Velocity

Velocity is the rate of change of displacement. Unlike speed, velocity is a vector quantity.

## Key Points

- Velocity has both magnitude and direction
- Velocity can be positive or negative
- Average velocity = Displacement / Time

## Difference from Speed

While speed is always positive, velocity can be negative if an object moves in the opposite direction to the reference point.

subtopics.title: Acceleration
subtopics.content:
# Acceleration

Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity.

## Formula

```
Acceleration = Change in Velocity / Time
a = (v - u) / t
```

Where:
- a = acceleration
- v = final velocity
- u = initial velocity
- t = time

## Units

Acceleration is measured in meters per second squared (m/s²).

subtopics.title: Newton's First Law
subtopics.content:
# Newton's First Law of Motion

An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.

## Also Known As

The Law of Inertia

## Real-World Examples

- A book on a table remains at rest
- A hockey puck sliding on ice continues moving
- Passengers lurch forward when a car brakes suddenly

subtopics.title: Newton's Second Law
subtopics.content:
# Newton's Second Law of Motion

The acceleration of an object depends on the mass of the object and the force applied.

## Formula

```
F = ma
```

Where:
- F = force (Newtons)
- m = mass (kg)
- a = acceleration (m/s²)

## Key Insight

The greater the force, the greater the acceleration. The greater the mass, the smaller the acceleration for the same force.

subtopics.title: Newton's Third Law
subtopics.content:
# Newton's Third Law of Motion

For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

## Examples

- When you push against a wall, the wall pushes back with equal force
- Rockets propel forward by expelling gas backward
- When swimming, you push water backward and move forward

subtopics.title: Work
subtopics.content:
# Work

Work is done when a force causes displacement.

## Formula

```
Work = Force × Displacement × cos(θ)
W = F × d × cos(θ)
```

## Units

Work is measured in Joules (J).

## Key Points

- No work is done if there is no displacement
- Maximum work when force and displacement are in the same direction

subtopics.title: Kinetic Energy
subtopics.content:
# Kinetic Energy

Kinetic energy is the energy possessed by an object due to its motion.

## Formula

```
KE = (1/2) × m × v²
```

Where:
- KE = kinetic energy (Joules)
- m = mass (kg)
- v = velocity (m/s)

## Important Note

Kinetic energy depends on the mass and the square of the velocity. Doubling velocity quadruples kinetic energy!

subtopics.title: Potential Energy
subtopics.content:
# Potential Energy

Potential energy is stored energy due to an object's position or configuration.

## Gravitational Potential Energy

```
PE = mgh
```

Where:
- PE = potential energy (Joules)
- m = mass (kg)
- g = gravitational acceleration (9.8 m/s²)
- h = height (m)

## Conservation of Energy

Total mechanical energy (KE + PE) remains constant in the absence of friction.

courses.title: Basic Mathematics for Problem Solving
courses.description: Core mathematical concepts used in science and everyday problem solving.

subtopics.title: Variables and Expressions
subtopics.content:
# Variables and Expressions

A variable is a symbol (usually a letter) that represents an unknown value.

## Algebraic Expressions

An algebraic expression combines variables, numbers, and operations.

### Examples

- `3x + 5`
- `2y - 7`
- `x² + 4x + 4`

## Evaluating Expressions

To evaluate an expression, substitute the variable with a number and calculate.

subtopics.title: Solving Linear Equations
subtopics.content:
# Solving Linear Equations

A linear equation is an equation where the highest power of the variable is 1.

## Standard Form

```
ax + b = c
```

## Steps to Solve

1. Isolate the variable term
2. Divide by the coefficient

### Example

Solve: `2x + 6 = 14`

```
2x = 14 - 6
2x = 8
x = 4
```

subtopics.title: Inequalities
subtopics.content:
# Inequalities

Inequalities show the relationship between two expressions that are not equal.

## Symbols

- `>` greater than
- `<` less than
- `≥` greater than or equal to
- `≤` less than or equal to

## Solving Inequalities

Follow the same steps as equations, but reverse the inequality when multiplying or dividing by a negative number.

subtopics.title: Area of Shapes
subtopics.content:
# Area of Shapes

Area measures the space inside a 2D shape.

## Common Formulas

### Rectangle
```
Area = length × width
```

### Triangle
```
Area = (1/2) × base × height
```

### Circle
```
Area = πr²
```

Where r is the radius.

subtopics.title: Perimeter
subtopics.content:
# Perimeter

Perimeter is the distance around a shape.

## Formulas

### Rectangle
```
Perimeter = 2(length + width)
```

### Square
```
Perimeter = 4 × side
```

### Circle (Circumference)
```
Circumference = 2πr
```

subtopics.title: Pythagorean Theorem
subtopics.content:
# Pythagorean Theorem

In a right triangle, the square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of squares of the other two sides.

## Formula

```
a² + b² = c²
```

Where:
- c = hypotenuse (longest side)
- a, b = other two sides

## Example

If a = 3 and b = 4, then:
```
c² = 3² + 4² = 9 + 16 = 25
c = 5
```

subtopics.title: Function Notation
subtopics.content:
# Function Notation

A function relates an input to an output.

## Notation

```
f(x) = expression
```

## Example

If `f(x) = 2x + 3`, then:
- `f(1) = 2(1) + 3 = 5`
- `f(5) = 2(5) + 3 = 13`

## Domain and Range

- **Domain**: All possible input values (x)
- **Range**: All possible output values (y)

subtopics.title: Linear Functions
subtopics.content:
# Linear Functions

A linear function produces a straight line when graphed.

## Slope-Intercept Form

```
y = mx + b
```

Where:
- m = slope (rate of change)
- b = y-intercept (where line crosses y-axis)

## Slope

```
Slope = Rise / Run = (y₂ - y₁) / (x₂ - x₁)
```

subtopics.title: Rate of Change
subtopics.content:
# Rate of Change

Rate of change describes how one quantity changes in relation to another.

## Average Rate of Change

```
Average Rate = Change in Output / Change in Input
```

## Real-World Applications

- Speed (distance per time)
- Price changes (dollars per item)
- Population growth (people per year)

## In Functions

For a linear function, the rate of change is constant and equals the slope.
